one_liner: A collaborative approach to design that involves stakeholders directly in the development process to ensure the final product meets their needs.
how_it_works: This methodology consists of three main phases: observation and inspiration, in-situ co-design through prototyping, and longitudinal evaluation. Initially, researchers observe and interview users to gather insights about their needs. Then, low-fidelity prototypes are developed and refined through collaborative sessions with stakeholders, allowing for iterative feedback. Finally, the prototypes are deployed in real-world settings to evaluate their effectiveness and gather further user feedback for refinement.

steps: 1. Conduct initial observations and interviews to understand user needs.
2. Develop a low-fidelity prototype based on initial insights.
3. Engage stakeholders in co-design sessions to define functionalities and interactions.
4. Iterate on the prototype based on user feedback.
5. Deploy the prototype in a real-world setting for evaluation.
6. Collect user feedback and performance data during the deployment.
7. Refine the design based on longitudinal evaluation results.
algorithm.input_format: User requirements, environmental context, low-fidelity prototypes.
algorithm.output_format: Refined assistive robot design and functionality tailored to user needs.

parameters.name: iteration_count
parameters.effect: More iterations can lead to better alignment with user needs.

parameters.name: deployment_duration
parameters.effect: Longer deployment allows for more comprehensive feedback.

parameters.name: evaluation_duration
parameters.typical_value: 10 months total (8 months design + 2 months evaluation)
parameters.effect: Extended evaluation provides deeper insights into user adoption and satisfaction.

complexity.practical_note: The methodology is resource-intensive due to the need for stakeholder involvement and iterative processes.

use_when: Designing assistive robots for healthcare settings.
Engaging with stakeholders who have limited experience with robotic technologies.
Seeking to align robotic functionalities with real-world user needs.
avoid_when: The user group has extensive prior experience with robotic systems.
Rapid prototyping is required without stakeholder involvement.
The project timeline does not allow for iterative feedback.
common_mistakes: Neglecting to involve all relevant stakeholders in the design process.
Rushing through the prototyping phase without adequate feedback.
Failing to adapt the design based on user feedback during evaluation.

strengths: Ensures the final product is closely aligned with user needs.
Facilitates the discovery of diverse user perspectives.
weaknesses: May lead to scope creep if not managed properly.
Requires skilled facilitation to manage stakeholder interactions.

compared_to.verdict: Use participatory design when user involvement is critical for success.
